commentBody: 51D/66A was kind of a Natick for me... made a guess on the crossing letter that turned out to be correct. Of course I had no idea what that letter stands for until I followed the link in the column...
Fun! Satisfying and timely theme, ZEBRACOLTS over OMELETBAR was worth the trouble it took to make it work. Thanks!
Easy but fun and enjoyed the theme! Nice Tuesday puzzle.

I don‚Äôt often comment on Tuesday puzzles, but this one offered a smidge more resistance than usual and had a cute theme to boot.  I had a little problem in the SW corner because  I tried solocups before TOGOCUPS and imsogone instead of IMSODONE.  Adam brogy did look a little suspect, but I didn‚Äôt know Adam BRODY (never having watched the OC).  And names being what they are Brogy seemed at least as plausible as Walthew.  When I couldn‚Äôt spot a mistake anywhere else in the puzzle, The D dawned on me

Loved the zebracolts, and the picture hint that also included the theme!  
Very easy & fast. 
Still cringing from GoHAM. While I appreciate the physique of the gentleman who remove 100+ pounds of weights from an exercise machine so I could use it, I'm a bit too "polite"  for that.

I'm already seeing other commenters had the same problem I did, bottom left corner.

GOHAM and ESME.  I've never read a Twilight book, but I still know there is a character Edward Cullen.  If you did not read the books, there is no way you could possibly know there is another Cullen named ESME.  And then 'GO HAM', that might as well be YASSIFY.  Combined with IMSODONE and TOGOCUPS, answers that aren't that niche but are awkward enough that nobody is getting them without most of the crossing clues.

And thankfully the jewelry theme that helped me get BRODY by figuring out BROOCH or I wouldn't have gotten that either.

2nd try. The first one was written before the first comment posted around 10:15. 

I guarantee the big topic of this set of comments will be GO HAM/ESME. Not knowing Twilight beyond Bella, Jacob and the other guy, it seemed that only ESME made sense, but it was 100% a guess. And GO HAM doesn‚Äôt make any sense at all unless you‚Äôre familiar with the rap song, or you‚Äôve looked up that the pig meat here really stands for ‚Äúhard a (a) mother.‚Äù
TIL I learned GOHAM (or is it GO HAM?). Guess it had to happen one day.

Figured out the Jewelry box theme quickly which helped with Brody because I don‚Äôt watch OC but I do know that Brooch doesn‚Äôt have an A in it. Don‚Äôt like seeing GOHAM on a Tuesday. I consider myself somewhat current on modern 6-7 slang as a 7th grade teacher, but haven‚Äôt crossed GO HAM yet. Wanted Lags instead of owes so was off a bit in the NE for a while. I am not a TwiHard but I do enjoy the books and it took me a few 6-7 seconds to remember Esme was also a Cullen besides Emmet, Carlisle and Edward. Had Octave before Octane. Still came in 2 under my average

For Esme with blood and pallor! (JD Salinger meets Twilight)

For Estee with Dove and parlor! (JD Salinger meets Estee Lauder)

Well I got the Go Ham one (not that I thought it was kosher) but for some reason had to spend a long time fly-specking ... OOPH rather than OOPS as the problem. Oops.  I figured HOBBING is some kind of slang for bawling. After all, once you put GO HAM in a puzzle, all bets are off: anything goes. 

All this time, I thought SIRI stood for something (Speech Interactive Response Interface) but no...that turns out to be a BACKRONYM (an acronym invented after the fact). It just sounds nice, which for some reason I find another sad sign of the decay of modern civilization. Nonsense used to mean something!

Nice to have a theme gimmick thrown in. Fun.

Some tricky crosses.

Maybe let's give aldi and aloe a break and bring back Oreo ¬Ø\_(„ÉÑ)_/¬Ø

Such a fun puzzle, Adrianne, with just enough pull to be a Tuesday‚Äôs best. 

I cannot believe [Child‚Äôs living room hideaway] SOFA FORT has never been used before. I got it right away. I can‚Äôt wait to see more from you again, Adrianne.

I was mostly charmed by this Tuesday puzzle, ZEBRACOLTS and SOFAFORTS and TOGOCUPS and all. Not a very flashy (jewelry notwithstanding) theme but well executed. 
I am going to admit here that my integrity is being put to the test today.I have always said that the behavior and political correctness (or lack there of) of a well known celebrity should not reflect on their inclusion in the grid. I‚Äôve also said that acronyms or other allusions to profanity that aren‚Äôt overt or inflammatory should be fair game. Now I‚Äôm faced with GOHAM which I had  never heard of‚Äîand looking it up I see it is attributed to one of the most offensive people I can think of and stands for one of the more offensive words I can think of (I‚Äôm cool with the F word which can be flippant but the M word is has no place in the vernacular, IMHO.) Nevertheless I am going to stand by my prior statements and say it‚Äôs apparently a slang term, it‚Äôs not spelled out, and the particular  celebrity origin of it does not make it off limits. I would have avoided it like the plague, personally, but I‚Äôm not going  to rail against the constructor or the editors for including it. There, glad I got that off my chest.

Fun, charming little puzzle.

I'm so often on the wrong side of the generational gap on certain clues*, so I'll take the GO HAM gimme as a rare piece of luck.

That said, I might have to disagree with our dear columnist about the term's origin! While the GO HAM acronym was popularized in the 2011 song, the term predates it, and was not associated with "hard as a ************" prior to the song's release. That places this bit of slang firmly in the backronym category. 

Anyway! Thanks to our constructor for the puzzle, and I'll see you folks on Wednesday. 

*"Who is that 1970s actress? Who is that 1980s American politician?" Tragically, I never know.
TBH, today my favorite part of solving today's puzzle was the photo and caption Caitlin chose to accompany her post.

This puzzle is a reminder of something driving me crazy lately (past year or two) - I think there has been a marked increase in the number of people pronouncing JEWELRY as jewlery.

There have always been some, but I feel I hear it everywhere now - by educated podcast hosts and guests (looking at you, NPR and NYT's The Daily), the nightly news, it seems *everyone* is mispronouncing JEWELRY. It's SO common that I fear it's on the verge of becoming an accepted alternative.

This puzzle contains the punchline to my favorite joke‚Ä¶ What is the difference between a Vietnamese restaurant and an Indian restaurant?

One is Pho profit and one is Naan profit! 

(Cue the laughter!) and Thank Yoi!
TIL about going HAM. I don‚Äôt see much of that in my future; I don‚Äôt even like pork products. And I am definitely not taking life advice from Kanye. I guess that makes me SAM. (I am not ashamed.)
Anyone else have ‚ÄúSue‚Äù as a [Good name for a chef?]?

As some of you have been unable to avoid knowing, my Blue Jays are engaged in the World Series with the LA Dodgers. The Jays won Game 1 in Toronto on Friday night. Then there was some unpleasantness on Saturday night. (Ahem)
Game 3 is being played tonight in LA and it has been a thriller. We are in the 10th inning (baseball's version of overtime), tied at 5-5. The lead has gone back and forth, with some sparkling fielding, some big hits, some acute pitching, some shocking umpiring, and some errors and sloppiness. It's on the knife's edge and LA has home-field advantage. Stay tuned.

It would an appear that the second A in HAAM is missing‚Ä¶. üòÄ 

Never heard of the expression and never read Twilight so like most others commenting I just entered M. 

My last was the A in TAZO. I‚Äôve never had boba tea and American brands don‚Äôt travel well and  the particular firm is TAUB so I don‚Äôt, as you say over in America, patronise it.

Another almost victim of the SW corner. No clue on the encouraging phrase, or the actor or the Twilight character (don't believe that any of my kids read it, and certainly didn't see the move). Was debating between BRaDY or BRODY, and luckily went with the O because I figured the phrase started "GO", not "Ga". So I finally ended up with GOHA_ and ran the alphabet to finish the puzzle. Also had lagS before OWES, which cost me a bit of time and consternation.

Otherwise, it was a fun puzzle to solve, so thanks, Adrianne.

"Did your jeweler share any pearls of wisdom with you?"
"No, I'll have to give him a ring."

("Or just brooch the subject.")
Here for the GOHAM/ESME drama
I guess this puzzle appealed to the young‚Äôuns like me, I didn‚Äôt have any problems with that particular 51D/66A crossing. Hope everyone had a smooth solve otherwise.
Ahh the famous ‚Äúgo ham‚Äù. I hear that so often from those youngsters

This GenXer didn‚Äôt have any issues with the ESME/GO HAM crossing. I did read the Twilight series while on full bed rest during my last pregnancy, so there‚Äôs that. 
Sitting here watching Game 3, top of the 13th inning. Will Klein is the only pitcher left in the bullpen and his mom is going to the game tomorrow night. ü§ûüèº they don‚Äôt need to use him tonight. This is a nail biter!! Back to the puzzle, I loved answers like ZEBRA COLTS and SOFA FORTS. I‚Äôm really enjoying all of Adrianne‚Äôs puzzles and look forward to the next ones ‚ò∫Ô∏è
A NAAN is baked in a tandoor, not a tandoori. Tandoori is an adjective.

There are phrases that immediately take you back to being a kid, when fun was worry-free, didn‚Äôt involve taking an Uber, cost (you) nothing, and the only polarizing issue was whether or not you did, in fact, throw like the little girl you were. 

Hello, SOFA FORT.

Tonight I paid the price for being too cool for themes. I mean, who needs them?  Well, if I had just looked away from the clues for just a sec to check out the very classy theme, I‚Äôd have gone ham in the SW and been done much earlier.

GO HAM? Especially since I didn't know ES_E, that entry annoyed me as apparent gibberish, but only before I checked the link in the column ü§£. Nice! I cuss like a sailor, taking after my mother in that respect, so it's my kind of phrase üòÇ

I almost had to go HAM (shouldn't that be HaaMf?) in the NW corner, where the unknown TAZO crossed with a bobba tea topping, a kind of school, and a kind of bar.

I've only had bobba tea once in my life and didn't like it - what does this sickly sweet, bland horror have to do with my favorite, elegantly aromatic, unsweetened brews? It seemed much more akin to soda, which I also dislike (too sweet, offensively artificially flavored, doesn't slake thirst. Eww)

I have also seen an OMELET BAR just once - at a huge, soulless hotel in the new port district of Kopenhagen, if I remember correctly - and found it awkward. I get that it lets you have an omelet freshly made to order, rather than, say, the atrocious, dry mess hotels often serve under the label of scrambled eggs. But the queue! The queue! There was a single person making the omelets and a hotel-full of people who wanted one...

I appreciate today's puzzle must have been super hard to construct with the themed boxes taking up so much space and requiring very specific entries on two crossing levels. Given that fact, it's quite impressive how little junk fill there was. I rarely take the constructor's mastery into account when rating puzzles, but I'll make an exception today.

Fun! I love JEWELRY (I pronounce it jool-ree, hope that's right?) of all kinds and this is especially topical after the Louvre heist!

Just the idea of a ZEBRA COLT is today's "squee" moment for me ü¶ì

But didn't we have a whole discussion recently about how ORCAS aren't deep sea predators? I even remember looking it up and AI helpfully explaining to me that they hunt in the "the sunlit epipelagic zone" which is far from "deep sea". I feel like someone (maybe our AI friends) should summarize our daily nits and forward them to the editors so they can be duly noted for future puzzles. Right? Lol

As an 18yo I got neither Esme nor go ham but that's probably because I'm not very good at crosswords... 

Don't see why people are so pressed about one or two pop culture references even when the crossword is still possible to solve with crossing clues 

Unknown references are inevitable parts of crosswords you'll have to accept especially as younger people start making and solving puzzles

+ I'm not exactly sure when the phrase "go ham" started being used but I wouldn't say they are exactly "under 20" references as the twilight books were released around the time I was born...
Another fun puzzle. Was able to get most of what I didn‚Äôt know through the crosses. Always have to look up a name or two. Thanks, Adrianne! Y‚Äôall have a great Tuesday!

I don‚Äôt get the volume of the wailing over the ESME/GOHAM cross. I‚Äôve heard GOHAM before, it reminds me of a Melissa McCarthy sketch from SNL I‚Äôve tried to link below. TIL it is an acronym. I‚Äôve heard of Edward Cullen, without ever having paid the slightest attention to Twilight. So, I‚Äôd never have gotten ESME‚Ä¶who knew vampires had nuclear families? But, anticipating the jewelry fill, like brooch, felt like it allowed for huge leaps forward in the fill. Today was a rare day for me, completion without having to look at the Wordplay column first. Enjoyed this puzzle very much. https://www.instagram.com/reel/DERUj7sxXdq/?igsh=NTc4MTIwNjQ2YQ==

I thought this was a solid  Tuesday puzzle. I was not bothered about the SW corner despite not knowing GOHAM (note to self: try phrase next gym visit), ESME (I was just missing the M, but it‚Äôs a fairly popular name here so an easy guess) or BRODY (but I thought it had to be GO something given the clue).

What‚Äôs this about some baseball tournament?  Is it now a real World Series because you‚Äôre letting the Canadians play?  Cue snarky responses!
A fine crossword, however I really don't appreciate the inclusion of Playboi Carti. Especially just one week after his latest allegations
GOHAM is a term no 71 year old lady would ever know and one I‚Äôm sorry I‚Äôve had to learn.

I think it's gotta be a new Tuesday record for me at 7 min. Thought this was easy breezie and easier than many Mondays. The theme was nice because I could use it to actually help solve the puzzle ... It wasn't  just some convoluted thing that you understand after you get all the clues...

In accepting this award for correctly completing todays puzzle,
I'd like to thank BROOCH for giving me BRODY,
and I'd especially like to thank my old friend ESME for giving me GO HAM.

I couldn't have done it without you.

In spite of paying exactly zero attention to the Fall Classic now in progress, I found this David Kwong puzzle to be very enjoyable. I hope the baseball fans here (and non-fans like me) will have some fun with it. It employs one of my favorite puzzle features. https://www.davidkwongmagic.com/crosswordsetc

G
       O
       H
       A
  ESME

The guess that's not really a guess.  

I'll bet that most people (like me) who "guessed", got it right. I have been guessing my way through puzzles for years.  The last time I had an incorrect guess was over 2 years ago.  Way too good odds, really.  It's more a factor of recognizing word patterns, choosing the most likely name, etc.  Whatever it is, it's something that improves the more you do it.  

Being too quick to look things up hampers the development of this skill.

Somehow dooks remind me of those magic eye pictures or an optical illusion (took me forever to see IMSODONE and not ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sod one‚Äù). 
I thought this puzzle was charming (excepting ELEM).

As one who often works buffet omelet bars, I can safely say that they are not "build-your-own." "Design-your-own," perhaps, but not "build-your-own"

Bad clue, NYT. Do better.




;-)
I  love that the column‚Äôs photo is literally a jewelry box.  (Hi, @Phishfinder!)

I enjoyed this puzzle. I was surprised that I finished it quicker than yesterday's, which was a tricky for a Monday to be fair. Overall, it a well-balanced Tuesday grid. Nice theme. 

To me, Tuesday puzzles should be "fast but a bit frustrating because of 3 or 4 tricky clues", which is exactly how I felt today. The pedants in the comment section are baseless in my opinion...

One answer that frustrates me as a music producer is "Longer than a midi" solving to "MAXI". I still don't really understand that answer other than just as a simple word play on "mid" and "max". In music production, "MIDI" is an extremely common communication protocol, so it was hard to see it as anything else.

Yesterday, Monday, my 388 solved streak disappeared, replaced by an incorrect 7 day [now 8] day run. 

Am I the only one?

LMK.

THX.

'For their research [about the effect of ZEBRA stripes on susceptibility to being fly-bit], they traveled to a horsefly-infested horse farm in Hungary'
NYT Science, Feb12, 2012

On behalf of all Magyar equine rights, I protest.

Not a big fan of the word "colt" to mean little horses. In the horse world, "colt" means a male horse up to age 4. So you can see colts as full-size horses racing at the track (although many question whether it's humane to race horses so young). I understand that the term here is common usage, but for horse people, the appropriate term is "foal" for horses of either sex under the age of 1. https://howtoownahorse.com/how-old-is-a-colt-horse/

For a while I had SPAR because those are from central Europe (but NL) and they're everywhere abroad. TIL there's ALDI in the US.

Fun puzzle, although BTU I Will always have to guess or infer, I don't think I will ever remember it even though it's in many puzzles.

This is Adrianne‚Äôs third NYT puzzle in four months and she‚Äôs been making puzzles less than two years.  That‚Äôs a wow in my book.

Already, she‚Äôs established that her puzzles will include answers with spark.  A grid with compelling answers is so much richer than simply a fill-in-the-blank.  It‚Äôs an outing with side trips that ping the brain with images, memories, reactions, and beauty.

Today I pictured an adorable ZEBRA COLT, a TEAPOT whistling and emitting steam, the striking TAZO logo.  I pictured a SNOB‚Äôs face with its distinctive eyebrows.  I fondly remembered my kids frantically building SOFA FORTs.  I tasted NAAN and drank in the aroma of an Indian restaurant.  I ‚ÄúWhaaa?‚Äù-ed at GO HAM, heard the fizz of an AERATEd drink, experienced soothing hot tub JETs. I melted over the beauty of the word REMNANT.

That is, my brain was pinging all over the place.  Who needs a virtual reality headset when a puzzle can take you so many places as you‚Äôre sitting in a chair?

So, Arianne, please keep packing your puzzles with pingers. Thank you for a fabulous outing today!

Another short streak says IM SO DONE (and not IM SO GONE).

Probably should have checked and might have seen that BRODY was more likely than BROGY.

Got ESME/GOHAM by guessing the M, since nothing else made any sense. Having GO in both TOGOCUPS and GOHAM might be considered a feature ... or maybe a bug.

Never fun to be beaten on a Tuesday.
Sorry guys, but 51d earned two of these‚Ä¶..üëé. Just not my cuppa boba.

This puzzle wins my award for Most Beautiful-Most Repulsive references.  You already know which one is most repulsive.  But the photo of the sparkly "frisky little zebra pin" almost makes up for it.

As an aside, perhaps the claim that this puzzle "belongs in the Louvre" is a bit of an unkind dig at that institution in its time of woe.
"Go ham"??? I hope I remember that one for future puzzles. But I almost certainly won't.
LOL Let's goooo--repping the younger generations with GO HAM. (You can see the difference in the comments, fellow solvers--no harm in some inter-generational competition!)
Fun puzzle, just right for a Tuesday.

Tough Tuesday for me. A whole lot of working the crosses and even had to look up a couple of things. Six debut answers and more than a couple of them that were unfamiliar. No big deal. 

One answer history search today was for SQUALOR, wondering about one specific thing. Only five appearances and 'Esme' was in the clue only once. But also did a search for ESME and... that's been an answer 176 times, and.. 'Salinger' was in the clue -- 107 times. (I can't help but wonder how many will be familiar with that). 

And, of course I have a puzzle find today. I'll put that in a reply. 

....

I preferred the previous method of displaying personal stats in the crossword puzzle.  The old method displayed your current, average, and fastest solve times in one easy to read bar graph. Would it be possible to switch back to that superior method?
Easy puzzle for me, but I can't fathom how the creator managed the shaded squares. Very cool.

Yikes....it's only Tuesday, guys!  No matter what, you can't make me read/watch the "Twilight" trash.  
Wanted a YETI CUP for the beverage container.
51D is a mystery, and crossing with a vampire ...well, No Fair!
Plus
What?  No PEARLS?
That makes me wonder where I left my RINGs this time; they're not on the nifty little ring-minder here on the dining room table...
Hmm.  Later, gators!

Yeesh, based on the comments, the editors and creator were asleep at the wheel with this one. Several incorrect entries.

I found it fun, if a bit tricky in the wrong ways. I‚Äôm not sure I understand CAPT for its clue Cook. ZEBRACOLTS tripped me up, as I‚Äôve never heard them called colts.
SOFAFORTS when I and everyone I know always called them pillow forts. WACKO and SIRI were lame ‚ÄúI guess?‚Äù answers. Not satisfying to solve. I guess sch. means school. In my world it means schedule/d. 

Yes, I realize some of these are me-issues. But I‚Äôm the player, I‚Äôm the commenter, and you‚Äôre just mad. Have a cookie. üç™üç™üç™

I just followed a Reddit thread for the mysterious (at least to me) phrase ‚Äúgo ham‚Äù. Apparently the source is the always sagacious and sensitive Ye, but the range of interpretations, ie guesses, across the thread makes it clear that I (old, white female devoid of hipness, ignorant of rap culture) am not the only one who is confused.
GO HAM, more than anything else, sounds like it could be a Premier League cheer.

GO HAM, more than anything, sounds like a Premier League cheer.

(Second try.)



I'm sporadically having trouble getting short posts to appear.


Do we have to go back to adding filler at the end for the emus?

By the way, one of the most moving Constructor‚Äôs Notes I can recall came with Adrianne‚Äôs first puzzle. Here‚Äôs the link: https://www.nytimes.com/2025/06/19/crosswords/daily-puzzle-2025-06-20.html .
Worst puzzle in a long time.

Another dull, rainy day here, but we celebrate the badly needed rain. The wild life is in short supply, as they‚Äôre likely headed south‚Ä¶ waaaay south. The diving birds should be arriving within the next few weeks from the north for their winter vacation. The call of the loon is so eerie, yet calming, and we await their return. No HAM comment from me; a quick scan says they‚Äôve quickly become the topic of the day But‚Ä¶ I like how CHO and PHO crossed, albeit two separate countries. I once liked Margaret Cho‚Äôs standup, especially her mocking of her Korean mom. Having been on station in Korea twice, that part of her schtick made sense. The old mama sans have that vibe. The PHO reminded me of this episode of Modern Family. I love the Dr.‚Äôs reaction. (Note the well-place apostrophe) https://youtu.be/9bibxxo1m2Q?si=inzu0R8Qt4Tp1P4V
Based on a quick review of the comments, I might be in the minority as to my familiarity with ‚ÄòGo ham‚Äô. And I‚Äôm a vegan fwiw.
I doubled my time troubleshooting before realizing that ICE was in fact ICY. Damn you, Adam BRODE.

JEWELleRY, for our British friends.

GO HAM was a bit ham-fisted.

Super-silly? WACKO is darker, more deranged than silly.

YMMV.
Love the zebra brooch.

I guarantee the big topic of this set of comments will be GO HAM/ESME. 

Not knowing Twilight beyond Bella, Jacob and the other guy, it seemed that only ESME made sense, but it was 100% a guess. And GO HAM doesn‚Äôt make any sense at all unless you‚Äôre familiar with the rap song, or you‚Äôve looked up that the pig meat here really stands for ‚Äúhard a (a) mother.‚Äù
My 404 day streak literally almost ended on a Tuesday with that ridiculous GOHAM/ESME corner. Not cool! Never heard of these two in my life.
Just 2014 left to go in the archive.

I've never watched the OC, but I loved Adam Brody in "Nobody Wants This".  I thought it was hilarious - my Jewish mother definitely did not.

That SW corner was a bit sticky, wasn't it?

Question for anyone complaining about completing the crossing ‚ÄúES_E‚Äù x ‚ÄúGOHA_‚Äù: can you name a single letter, other other than M‚Äù, that seems like even a marginally plausible candidate here?
General Tso has shrimp too? Who knew!?!?
Kudos to the finder of that zebra pin photo! Perfection, and a good back story to boot. And now I want a zebra pin.
Esme always makes me think of Salinger.
Go ham or go home.

Miss me? Summer iPad solving does not easily offer the comment page.... so I do not comment.  Or, offer bad Tom Swifties.

Back in the land of "big mac" till May.

HAM, reminds me of Penny from FB.

Fun solve.

Thank you Adrianne
When I had ZE I immediately thought, "zebra colts." Some days the brain is quicker than usual.  Lucky me!
Esme always evokes Salinger
Ham-fisted for a Tuesday.

Pretty good time for me today. Only held up by SOFAtent rather than SOFAFORT. Oddly, having never read the books or seen the movies, I still knew it was ESME Cullen. One of those factoids that's just in the pop culture air, I guess.

I, too, did not know GOHAM or ESME, but running the alphabet did the trick. With luck, I'll remember it for next time. Good workout for a Tuesday. Finally caught up on puzzles after being away for the weekend.

"Go home, Esme, you're drunk."
"Well, can I get a TO GO CUP?"
Anyone doubting the existence of an OMELET BAR should come to Harvey Mudd for weekend brunch! No HAM for me.

I was surprised to see that others had the same problems as me with certain clues, doesn't happen often.

I did think TOGO had something to do with travellers in that East African country's  "people on the move".
I don't know the phrase I'M SO DONE, or TAZO and never heard of an OMELETTE BAR.

Otherwise, all very doable and I got all my tricky one with crossers.
TIL "Go ham." Not that I'll ever use it IRL.

Toronto, as least in days of yore, was known as Hogtown.
So: go ham!

Nice memories of when our granddaughter was new, cooing as she looked up at the dangling flip phone.

Fancy puzzle. If you look at the right angle, the RING and the HOOP are diamonds!
GOHAM crossing ESME was a total guess.
Stuck in Reykjavik during a record-breaking snowstorm and got my best ever Tuesday time!
GOHAM crossing not one but two out of date tween pop culture names was a bridge too far for me, that corner should have been reworked before publication.

I was surprised to see so many comments troubled about GOHAM! To me at least, "to go ham" is the natural extension of "hamming it up," which to my knowledge has been in use for many a decade. Many such cases. Ham it up, go hog-wild, etc.
From today's mini: "What might be requested after spinning around on an iPad". Crosses revealed TIP. Was this just clumsy cluing or can someone explain the connection?

My comment from close to 12 hours ago is still stuck in the filter.  (I used "stars" to emulate the GOHAM punchline).  

The gist was that ESME was the 344th most popular girls name in 2024 according to the US Social Security Administration, who's website still works and no snark (imagine that).  

As a boy's name, not in the top 1000, which appears to be the cutoff.  

A fun one today.   Thanks.
Perhaps it is my bias as a younger person, but "Go Ham" was one of the first clues I filled in once I had the G. I was surprised to see it was so difficult and contentious.
LOL at "GO HAM" & its definition when I looked it up. Yeah, well, I'm 64....
I left the M in ESME and GOHAM blank until I finished the puzzle, intending to run the alphabet on it, but entered M first on a whim, and the music played!

I really wanted Great name for a chef? to be Sue. Alas, I finally let go. 
I'm still recovering from the weekend doozies. This was a fun one. 
And now I know a very different meaning for GOHAM than what I had in mind üòÇ
Cemented by NYT crossword. ü§ü (143) üíõ
I don't just go ham, I go ham and cheese.  Maybe even with mustard if I'm feeling crazy.
Love this constructor.  Esp her Sept 21 puzzle, but like this one a lot too.  Thanks!
I had never heard of either clued artist and I envy my past self for that. Some truly terrible music featured in this puzzle.
GOHAM?  Never heard this, what dies it mean?

No one in the tattoo community refers to an artist as an INKER. In fact, most tattoo artists would never use ‚Äúink‚Äù as a verb or to refer to a tattoo (only when discussing the actual material itself). A quick Google search tells me that artists that work on comic books are called inkers; that would have been a more accurate clue.

You wouldn't publish the words in ""GO HAM". What makes you think that I want them in my head?

If I understand this correctly [didn't feel like further internet searching] the M in GOHAM stands for one of the 9 Nasty Words you can't say on television. So I'm using this as an excuse to plug a favorite author and book, linguist John Mcwhorter's Nine Nasty Words. One of his points-that surely only a linguist could notice--is that the N- and M- words can become, grammatically, pronouns! As in:
  I got bitten by a spider! The M-- came out of nowhere! M- replaces IT, you see.

@SP ham is short for mayhem and the phrase ‚Äúgo ham‚Äú was originated in 1977 (though it meant something completely different back, then). The lewd meaning imposed on it as an backronym by the hip-hop world definitely came as a later ‚Äúinnovation.‚Äú

@Kurt

So what did HAM originally stand for?

@Jim It never stood for anything, that's what "backronym" implies. It was just a word, and someone invented an acronym that would fit the letters.

"Ham" is old slang for overacting. So someone could be a "ham" if they are overly dramatic, or could be "hamming it up". It's easy to see how that can morph to "go ham", meaning trying too hard.

@Matt Well, I'm an old-fashioned girl myself and hate most change, epecially in language.  Yet, I must admit that for the most part it's simply personal prejudice combined with a certain snobbishness.  If language did not change, the English I love would never have come to be.  The drivers of such change are not for mere mortals to determine, but it stands to reason they would not be language conservatives like myself.  So, although the disappearance of the true meaning of "enormity" and the consternating substitution of "loose" for lose - among too many other changes to name - will continue to get my goat, I don't expect the English language will be asking my persmission to evolve. More's the pity.  ;)

Wait, what? People are pronouncing ‚Äúvulnerable‚Äù in a manner that involves eliding the first ‚ÄúL‚Äù? I wonder if that‚Äôs a regional and/or generational thing ‚Äî I have yet to hear it myself.

@Margaret because humans haven't been mostly literate for most of our history, pronunciation changes have been the primary mechanism for language change. These pronunciation changes have been eventually mirrored by spelling changes (although not always-- there's a lag). Now that written languages are widespread, it makes sense that spellings would be slow to follow spoken changes and perhaps might not even happen.

That's a change in the form of language change! But not less legitimate.

@Sam Lyons

Right? For me it's not phrases though but sights. As kids my friends and I spent a lot of time outside, in the undeveloped no-man's-land between the apartment buildings of Warsaw's government-built Ursyn√≥w district. It had been designed as a beautiful and liveable garden city in the boom decade of the 1970s, but the economic crisis of the 1980s meant only the blocks of flats were constructed. The untended land all around, dotted with heaps of earth and mounds of concrete rubble left over from construction work was our playground. We loved it.

These days every time I see clumps of weeds it takes me back to my childhood. The pangs of nostalgia are almost too hard to take. Everything was so much simpler and joyous... Our forts were made of twigs, rubbish and construction detritus, but I had some of the best fun of my life in them.

Btw. Nowadays Ursyn√≥w is one of Warsaw's greenest districts, among the best places to live in the city. The prosperity brought about by democracy and market economy finally allowed the realization of the original vision of its designers. Marek Budzy≈Ñski, Ursyn√≥w's chief urbanist and architect - now in his late 80s - lives here. My wife and I bought a condo in Ursyn√≥w, too, and we love it. Everything is very different than it was, but the ghosts of my childhood are everywhere.

@Andrzej,

Utah has some of the most beautiful scenic areas in the whole country. The rest areas along the I-70 interstate highway look like they could be national parks.

@Sam Lyons

It may sound so, but it was all my experience. I had one interaction with police in the US - for a minor thing that wasn't even illegal I was threatened with jail and encouraged to leave the state of Nevada. I have never experienced anything remotely as disturbing in any European country. The owner of a hotel in Northern California waved his huge gun before us to show us how safe his business was. I felt like leaving. We were asked about our religion at breakfast at a BnB by the other guests and we got strange looks when we declared our atheism, and a religious service was an integral part of a village fair in California. The Jeep we drove was described as mid sized by the rental company, yet it wouldn't fit in an average European parking space. The staff at most restaurants prostrated themselves before us - by a European standard, anyway - presumably working for their tips (which we always gave, even if the servers didn't sacrifice their human dignity for them). The roads, even the main highways, were horrible,  compared to relatively poor Poland, etc.

@Andrzej

I agree with most of what you said, except I didn't find my two-day adventure with the police in Warszawa a warm and fuzzy experience. And I was the victim!

@Times Rita

I can imagine. We had a similar experience in Spain - cold and not very helpful.

Anyway, I'm not saying this place is any better than any other, and certainly not by any and all metrics. It's just the way we do things over here is very different than in the US, and much of what seems normal to Americans is at best strange and possibly even disturbing and dangerous to me. I mean, I've nevel felt threatened by the police in Poland or elsewhere in the EU, not once in my life, and in Poland I've never seen a gun on anybody else than a policeman, security guard or hunter.

And then there are all the little things - the light switches, the water taps, the road signs, the generic garden furniture - it's all slightly different than here, which keeps making me feel out of place. It would probably take decades of living in the US for the feeling to go away.

@Andrzej
Explain the Nevada thing.  Sounds like there is more to that story.
@Sam Lyons We had piano forts! The best!

@Andrzej
Children find fun no matter what...  Your memory of playing with rubbish and detritus reminds me of our first apartment in Frankfurt am Main (1951)...  across the street from the PalmenGarten.  Our 'yard' had a 'fence' rigged up from odds and ends of shutters, scraps, etc.  We built little forts using material from the heaps of waste left by bombings--all bleached by weather to the same dull yellowish color.

@Sam Lyons
I left beautiful Washington State (Lake Sammamish!) in 1969 on a postgrad trip to Europe and only returned to visit family over the years. I‚Äôve been here to stay for many decades now.
European culture had always fascinated me, and it is still a thrill to experience it in so many forms: music, art, architecture - and not least: political discourse. 
I live in the very tame landscapes of northern Germany, and it took some time to adjust to land and people. At first seemingly strict and non-humorous people revealed themselves over time to be capable of deep, reliable friendships ‚Äî and also with keen senses of humor. Humor here is ubiquitous, just mostly different from the American and British versions. There are lovely landscapes here ‚Äî not as dramatic as in the U.S. West, but this densely populated country takes the protection of historical and environmental treasures seriously.
Sorry to go on and on‚Ä¶

@Lpr - Yes, and when that issue came up I pointed out that ORCAs can be found throughout the world oceans, far from coasts, in regions that would be described as the "deep sea." (The previous criticism made the erroneous claim that ORCAs were found only in coastal waters.) 

I have gone "deep-sea fishing" but I did not use lines that were several miles long. I was "deep-sea fishing" in very deep water, but my line was in the epipelagic, as were the fish I was angling for.

Deep-sea" does not mean "only found in the bathypelagic or hadal waters". It can also mean "regions of the ocean where the bottom is really far below you."

I'm in my 70s and don't live in another country. I had no idea about GOHAM, but only tried ESME because I knew that name from the short story  "For Esme, With Love and Squalor", by J. D. Salinger. I think I had to read that in high school, so I took a chance with the M.

@Yer

The issue everyone is complaining about is that both GO HAM and ESME are generational answers of a similar vintage (around 2010).  Crosses help when you know one of them, and constructors are usually good at crossing things that are narrowly known either with things that are widely known, or things that are known to a different demographic.  To make things worse, Tuesdays aren't supposed to have such obscure (to most) crossings.

I got it because ESME was the most likely name, and HAM was a word.  The crossing letter could have been T, since ESTE is a possible name (but is usually clued to Spanish), and HAT is also a word; if you don't know the right one, GO HAM and GO HAT make equal sense (or don't).

But I can easily see that it was a brutal cross, and my choice was definitely a guess...an experienced guess, no doubt, but still a guess.

For my money, this was a Tuesday version of the recent SUNRA x SANKA x PANDA crossing, which was also a total Natick for me‚Ä¶and also soluble through reasoning, without direct knowledge of the answers (though the reasoning step took me several minutes in that case, as opposed to a matter of seconds today).

@Bill
One more insight into the world of omelet bars:
At the hotel where I work, the kitchen will purchase for, and issue, us non-stick 8" omelet skillets. They then become our property, and we guard them carefully, clean them ourselves (don't use dish soap, wipe out with a microfiber towel only); I usually hide mine in my locker.
And woe to the person who touches our pans! One sous-chef in particular, a "pan-burner," covered for me on the line one morning, for about 45 minutes, and managed to completely destroy my pans--how did he do it so fast?

I wouldn't skip the covid jab. Sometimes I've had only a sore arm for a day, and sometimes felt flu-ey for several days.

No fever, but throat so painful she couldn't eat; went in the hospital, then suffered a-fib and had be shocked back to. I guess covid can trigger any underlying condition or vulnerability.
Anyway, beware a sore throat.

I got the new 'vid jab on Sept 15th; only a mildly sore arm for a day.

My earlier comment hasn't posted --- emus or Amazon cloud services? --- I did enjoy the puzzle, GO HAM notwithstanding.

@RiA
"Retrospectacle" is the name of a compilation album by the 1980's New Wave one-hit wonder Thoma Dolby. (A rather unfair moniker, as much of his music is quite fine, if unknown, and much could not be described as "New Wave.")  A rather clever title, as his signature look included little round wire frame glasses. (@Grant in Del. probably knows this.)

"M" for ESME seemed the most logical choice, although the name seems odd for a character from a 21st c. novel. (Although, checking her fictional "bio," she was born in 1895, in Columbus, Ohio.) But now I'm wondering who the other 68 Esmes were . . .

Discussed this with my PCP  just a couple of weeks ago; he is seeing only mildly ill covid-positive patients, and he is aware of my hypervigilant reaction to meds/vaccines/etc.  "Your body thinks it's being attacked," is how he put it.  The last booster, I had fever, chills, terrible body aches that prevented sleep/rest, weakness and dizziness--for days.  DHubby had a slightly sore arm, as most of our friends reported.  I'd be foolish not to take note of my body's message...
